017package org.microbean.loader;
018
019import java.lang.reflect.Type;
020
021import java.util.ArrayList;
022import java.util.List;
023import java.util.Map;
024import java.util.NoSuchElementException;
025import java.util.Properties;
026
027import java.util.function.Supplier;
028
029import org.microbean.invoke.FixedValueSupplier;
030
031import org.microbean.loader.api.Loader;
032
033import org.microbean.loader.spi.AbstractProvider;
034import org.microbean.loader.spi.Value;
035
036import org.microbean.path.Path;
037import org.microbean.path.Path.Element;
038
039import org.microbean.qualifier.Qualifiers;
040
041import org.microbean.type.JavaTypes;
042import org.microbean.type.Type.CovariantSemantics;
043
044/**
045 * An {@link AbstractProvider} that can return {@link Value}s backed
046 * by System properties.
047 *
048 * <p>While System properties are often casually assumed to be stable
049 * and {@link String}-typed, the exact opposite is true: System
050 * properties may contain arbitrarily-typed {@link Object}s under
051 * arbitrarily-typed keys, and the properties themselves {@linkplain
052 * System#setProperties(Properties) may be replaced} at any point.
053 * This means that all {@link Value}s supplied by this {@link
054 * SystemPropertyProvider} are {@linkplain Value#determinism()
055 * non-deterministic} and may change type and presence from one call
056 * to another.</p>
057 *
058 * <p>It is also worth mentioning explicitly that, deliberately, no
059 * type conversion of any System property value takes place in this
060 * class.</p>
061 *
062 * @author <a href="https://about.me/lairdnelson"
063 * target="_parent">Laird Nelson</a>
064 *
065 * @see System#getProperty(String, String)
066 *
067 * @see System#getProperties()
068 *
069 * @see System#setProperties(Properties)
070 *
071 * @see Properties#getProperty(String, String)
072 *
073 * @see Value#determinism()
074 */
075public class SystemPropertyProvider extends AbstractProvider {
076
077
078  /*
079   * Instance fields.
080   */
081
082
083  private final boolean flatKeys;
084
085  private final boolean onlyStrings;
086
087  private final boolean mutable;
088  
089
090  /*
091   * Constructors.
092   */
093
094
095  /**
096   * Creates a new {@link SystemPropertyProvider} that uses flat keys,
097   * does not presume that the only things stored in the System
098   * properties are {@link String}s, and honors the fact that System
099   * properties are mutable.
100   *
101   * @see #SystemPropertyProvider(boolean, boolean, boolean)
102   */
103  public SystemPropertyProvider() {
104    this(true, false, true);
105  }
106
107  /**
108   * Creates a new {@link SystemPropertyProvider}.
109   *
110   * @param flatKeys whether the key for a system property is derived
111   * from a {@link Path}'s {@linkplain Path#lastElement() last
112   * element}'s {@linkplain Element#name() name} only
113   *
114   * @param onlyStrings whether all System properties are expected to
115   * be {@link String}-typed
116   *
117   * @param mutable whether System properties should be treated as
118   * mutable (which they are, strictly speaking, but for many
119   * applications this may not matter in practice)
120   */
121  public SystemPropertyProvider(final boolean flatKeys,
122                                final boolean onlyStrings,
123                                final boolean mutable) {
124    super(onlyStrings ? String.class : null);
125    this.flatKeys = flatKeys;
126    this.onlyStrings = onlyStrings;
127    this.mutable = mutable;
128  }
129
130
131  /*
132   * Instance methods.
133   */
134
135
136  /**
137   * Returns a {@link Supplier} suitable for the System property
138   * represented by the supplied {@link Path}.
139   *
140   * <p>This method never returns {@code null}.  Its overrides may if
141   * they wish.</p>
142   *
143   * <p>The {@linkplain Path.Element#name() name} of the {@linkplain
144   * Path#lastElement() last element} of the supplied {@link Path} is
145   * taken to be the name of the System property value to retrieve.
146   * If the {@linkplain JavaTypes#erase(Type) type erasure} of the
147   * supplied {@link Path}'s {@link Path#qualified() qualified()}
148   * method {@linkplain Class#isAssignableFrom(Class) is assignable
149   * from} {@link String String.class}, then calls will be made by the
150   * returned {@link Value}'s {@link Value#get() get()} method to
151   * {@link System#getProperty(String)} before simple calls to {@link
152   * Properties#get(String) System.getProperties().get(String)}.</p>
153   *
154   * <p>Any {@link Supplier} returned by this method will be
155   * {@linkplain
156   * org.microbean.invoke.OptionalSupplier.Determinism#NON_DETERMINISTIC
157   * non-deterministic}, since system properties may change at any
158   * point.  Additionally, if the supplied {@link Path}'s {@linkplain
159   * Path#qualified() type} is not assignable from that borne by a
160   * System property value, then the {@link Supplier} will return
161   * {@code null} from its {@link Value#get() get()} method in such a
162   * case, indicating that the value is present but cannot be
163   * represented.  Overrides are strongly encouraged to abide by these
164   * conditions.</p>
165   *
166   * @param requestor the {@link Loader} seeking a {@link Value}; must
167   * not be {@code null}
168   *
169   * @param absolutePath an {@linkplain Path#absolute() absolute
170   * <code>Path</code>} for which a {@link Value} is being sought;
171   * must not be {@code null}
172   *
173   * @return a {@link Supplier} suitable for the System property whose
174   * name is represented by the supplied {@link Path}'s {@linkplain
175   * Path#lastElement() last <code>Element</code>}'s {@linkplain
176   * Path.Element#name() name}
177   *
178   * @exception NullPointerException if an argument for either
179   * parameter is {@code null}
180   *
181   * @nullability This method never returns {@code null} but its
182   * overrides may.
183   *
184   * @threadsafety This method is, and its overrides must be, safe for
185   * concurrent use by multiple threads.
186   *
187   * @idempotency This method is idempotent and deterministic.
188   * Overrides must be idempotent, but need not be deterministic.
189   * {@link Supplier}s returned by this method or its overrides are
190   * <em>not</em> guaranteed to be idempotent or deterministic.
191   */
192  @Override
193  protected Supplier<?> find(final Loader<?> requestor, final Path<? extends Type> absolutePath) {
194    assert absolutePath.absolute();
195    assert absolutePath.startsWith(requestor.path());
196    assert !absolutePath.equals(requestor.path());
197
198    // This is tricky.  System properties suck.
199    //
200    // System properties are mutable.  They can come and go at any
201    // point.  They can also be of any type.  If you set them to null,
202    // the "required" ones get re-initialized to newly sourced values.
203    // And so on.
204    //
205    // Next, while the keys are "flat", they are often naively assumed
206    // to represent a hierarchy.  But the naming scheme suggests that
207    // even in the case of the "required" properties the designers
208    // were thinking in terms of hierarchies.
209    //
210    // Anyway, suppose an absolute Path of "/com/foo/bar" (making up
211    // the syntax; "/" is a Path.Element separator; each "word" is a
212    // Path.Element name() value) has a size of 4 (the leading
213    // element's name is always "") (hierarchical).  Should this
214    // Provider respond by trying
215    // System.getProperties().getProperty("com.foo.bar")?
216    //
217    // Or should this Provider only accept a Path of "/com.foo.bar"
218    // whose size is 2 (flat), so that the name of only the *last*
219    // element is the property key ("com.foo.bar")?
220    //
221    // (The end call to System.getProperty() is the same, of course.)
222    //
223    // If we do the hierarchy case, we might run into spurious
224    // conflicts between this Provider and
225    // ProxyingProvider. "java.home", for example, is not really a
226    // hierarchy; "java.home" as a flat string is actually the name of
227    // the property in question and just happens to have "." in it.
228    //
229    // On the other hand, if we do the flat case, there isn't an easy
230    // way to override scalar nodes in a tree, and it seems at least
231    // moderately clear that the designers wanted these keys to be
232    // perceived as hierarchical in some fashion.
233
234    final String key = key(absolutePath, this.flatKeys);
235    if (key == null || key.isEmpty()) {
236      // System properties never permit null or empty keys.  See
237      // https://github.com/openjdk/jdk/blob/jdk-17+35/src/java.base/share/classes/java/lang/System.java#L1043-L1050.
238      return null;
239    }
240    final Type type = absolutePath.qualified();
241    if (CovariantSemantics.INSTANCE.assignable(type, String.class)) {
242      if (this.mutable) {
243        return () -> {
244          final String returnValue = System.getProperty(key);
245          if (returnValue == null) {
246            // System.getProperty() is documented to purposely conflate
247            // absence with null for some reason.
248            throw new NoSuchElementException(key);
249          }
250          return returnValue;
251        };
252      } else {
253        final String value = System.getProperty(key);
254        if (value == null) {
255          // System.getProperty() is documented to purposely conflate
256          // absence with null for some reason.
257          return null;
258        }
259        return FixedValueSupplier.of(value);
260      }
261    } else if (this.onlyStrings) {
262      return null;
263    } else if (this.mutable) {
264      // At this point we know that the requested type is not a
265      // supertype of String.  Therefore there's no point in calling
266      // System.getProperty(key) because you wouldn't be able to
267      // assign its (String) return value to the caller doing the
268      // requesting.  Therefore defaults are not in play because only
269      // System.getProperty() consults them.  Therefore we can treat
270      // the return value of System.getProperties() as just an
271      // ordinary Map.  We also know that is is a Properties instance,
272      // so we also know it is fully synchronized on itself.  Putting
273      // this all together we can tell definitively when a value has
274      // been explicitly and deliberately set to null versus when it
275      // is absent.
276      return () -> {
277        final Object returnValue;
278        final Map<?, ?> map = System.getProperties();
279        synchronized (map) {
280          if ((returnValue = map.get(key)) == null && !map.containsKey(key)) {
281            throw new NoSuchElementException(key);
282          }
283        }
284        if (returnValue == null || CovariantSemantics.INSTANCE.assignable(type, returnValue.getClass())) {
285          return returnValue;
286        }
287        return null;
288      };
289    } else {
290      final Object returnValue;
291      final Map<?, ?> map = System.getProperties();
292      synchronized (map) {
293        if ((returnValue = map.get(key)) == null && !map.containsKey(key)) {
294          return null;
295        }
296      }
297      if (returnValue == null || CovariantSemantics.INSTANCE.assignable(type, returnValue.getClass())) {
298        return FixedValueSupplier.of(returnValue);
299      }
300      return null;
301    }
302  }
303
304  /**
305   * Overrides the {@link AbstractProvider#path(Loader, Path)} method
306   * to return a (relative) {@link Path} consisting solely of the
307   * {@linkplain Path#lastElement() last element} of the supplied
308   * {@code absolutePath}.
309   *
310   * @param requestor the {@link Loader} seeking a {@link Value}; must
311   * not be {@code null}
312   *
313   * @param absolutePath an {@linkplain Path#absolute() absolute
314   * <code>Path</code>} for which a {@link Value} is being sought;
315   * must not be {@code null}
316   *
317   * @return a {@link Path} that will be {@linkplain
318   * Value#Value(Supplier, Path) used to build a <code>Value</code>}
319   * to be returned by the {@link #get(Loader, Path)} method
320   *
321   * @nullability This method does not, but overrides may, return
322   * {@code null}.
323   *
324   * @idempotency This method is, and its overrides must be,
325   * idempotent and deterministic.
326   *
327   * @threadsafety This method is, and its overrides must be, safe for
328   * concurrent use by multiple threads.
329   *
330   * @see AbstractProvider#path(Loader, Path)
331   */
332  @Override
333  @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
334  protected <T extends Type> Path<T> path(final Loader<?> requestor, final Path<T> absolutePath) {
335    return Path.of(absolutePath.lastElement());
336  }
337
338
339  /*
340   * Static methods.
341   */
342
343
344  /**
345   * Returns a {@link String} representation of the supplied {@link Path}.
346   *
347   * @param path the {@link Path} in question; must not be {@code
348   * null}
349   *
350   * @param flat whether the key is derived from the supplied {@link
351   * Path}'s {@linkplain Path#lastElement() last element}'s
352   * {@linkplain Element#name() name} only
353   *
354   * @return a {@link String} representation of the supplied {@link
355   * Path}
356   *
357   * @exception NullPointerException if {@code path} is {@code null}
358   *
359   * @nullability This method never returns {@code null}.
360   *
361   * @idempotency This method is idempotent and deterministic.
362   *
363   * @threadsafety This method is safe for concurrent use by multiple
364   * threads.
365   */
366  protected static final String key(final Path<?> path, final boolean flat) {
367    if (flat) {
368      return path.lastElement().name();
369    } else {
370      return path.stream()
371        .map(Element::name)
372        .filter(s1 -> !s1.isEmpty())
373        .reduce((s1, s2) -> String.join(".", s1, s2))
374        .orElse("");
375    }
376  }
377
378}
